Award.AwardTitle: Supercapacitive Swing Adsorption Modules and Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET - 1566201
PI: Landskron, K.

Gas separations are a key requirement for many of today's industrial operations and are important for environmental safety, human health, and energy production. For example, carbon capture, which is essentially a separation of carbon dioxide from nitrogen resulting from the combustion of natural gas or coal in a power plant, will avoid emission of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. Other important gas separations include recovery of hydrogen for industrial use, recovery of noble gases such as xenon from air, and separation of key light gas petrochemicals such as propane and propylene. In this project, a new gas separation technology - Supercapacitive Swing Adsorption - will be researched and designed. The project's approach will use capacitive energy to achieve the gas separation. This form of energy has the advantage that it can be recovered with minimal losses. As a consequence, the technique is promising to achieve gas separations with lower energy consumption compared with currently used methods. The energy efficiency of gas separations processes is very important for economic viability. In addition, Supercapacitive Swing Adsorption has a potential lower environmental footprint since it requires non-toxic, environmentally friendly chemical solvents and carbon-based materials as the adsorbent. Supercapacitive Swing Adsorption has the potential to be applicable to several important industrial gas separations. In this project the PI will focus on the separation of carbon dioxide from nitrogen because of the extreme importance of carbon capture and sequestration.

In contrast to conventional pressure and temperature swing adsorption processes, Supercapacitive Swing Adsorption offers an approach for full selectivity towards a targeted gas mixture component. In the process, the sorbent itself is reversibly altered by capacitive charge and discharge leading to a change in gas adsorption behavior. An electric double layer is formed and the targeted component is adsorbed in/on the electrode. Capacitive charge and discharge is a thermodynamically reversible process that can be operated with high energy efficiency, since a continuous current is not used and the gases are adsorbed similar to physisorption energetics. Supercapacitive Swing Adsorption modules will be tested for their performance in the separation of carbon dioxide from nitrogen as an example of carbon capture. The modules will allow for charge and discharge under continuous gas flow. The primary performance parameters of investigation will be energy efficiency, purity of the produced gas, gas adsorption capacity, and adsorption and desorption kinetics. To maximize the energy efficiency, the team will design electrodes with minimal internal resistance. The shape and morphology of the electrodes will be optimized with regard to charge and discharge kinetics as well as gas adsorption and desorption kinetics. To maximize the gas adsorption capacity the PI will perform experiments with increased voltage, explore new sorbent materials as electrodes, and test alternative electrolytes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The SSA effect is a new phenomenon with high potential for gas separation. Many gas separations are performed at the industrial scale. Examples are natural gas sweetening (CO2/CH4 separation), air separation (O2/N2 separation), carbon capture (CO2/N2 separation), H2 purification (CO2/H2 separation), and alkane/alkene separations. The energy costs associated with the separation and purification of industrial commodities currently represent around 15% of global energy production, and the demand for such commodities is projected to triple by 2050. In addition, gas separations have many environmental applications because they can reduce air pollution. SSA is a completely novel approach to tackle these important societal energy and environmental problems. It is the first gas separation technique which is based on capacitance and fundamentally different from all previously known gas separation techniques. In SSA, the electrical energy is shuttled in between the two SSA modules with minimal losses. In contrast to the most established gas separation methods, PSA and TSA, no pressure and temperature changes are required. SSA is clearly distinguished from electrochemical gas separation techniques. In electrochemical methods the chemical nature of the gas is altered in a redox process and a permanent current is necessary to drive the redox reaction. In contrast, SSA is based on capacitive adsorption of a gas, and thus there is no permanent current flow, and the electrical energy used to charge the capacitor can be recovered upon discharge. SSA should not be confused with Electrical Swing Adsorption (ESA), a technique with a similar name. ESA is only a specialized form of TSA. In ESA, desorption is accomplished by Joule heating of electrically conducting carbon materials, which involves irreversible conversion of useable electric energy into waste heat due to a permanent current flow. In SSA, the charge and discharge of the capacitor is accompanied by physisorptive adsorption and desorption of the gas. Unlike for physisorptive PSA and TSA methods, one gas in the mixture can be attracted to the sorbent while the other is repelled. This is not possible in TSA and PSA where always both gases are attracted and selectivity only results because the magnitude of the attractive forces is not the same. SSA requires only non-toxic, environmentally benign, chemically robust, and inexpensive materials, namely high surface area carbons and aqueous NaCl electrolytes. This is a huge benefit over amine-scrubbing techniques that employ toxic, volatile, and corrosive amines. Amines easily degrade in the presence of just small amounts of O2 and get easily deactivated by NOx and SOx impurities in gas mixtures. This is not possible for carbons and aqueous NaCl solutions. The modules and systems can be scaled similarly to fuel cells and capacitive deionization systems. There is no need for the development of a new scaling concept. An SSA system is completely stationary and does not require any moving parts. This is a difference to PSA and TSA techniques which require either the circulation of a liquid sorbent or the shuttling of a solid sorbent. No sweeping gases are required for SSA. The work is fundamental research because fundamentally new devices based on a fundamentally new phenomenon will produce fundamental data that reveals fundamental relationships between the chemical and structural parameters of sorbents and electrolytes and the thermodynamics and kinetics of SSA. SSA is a fundamentally new phenomenon that could be exploited for a whole range of gas separations, for example the separation of alkanes from alkenes, N2 from O2, or CO from H2, all of which are industrially applied. SSA also has implications for gas storage because gases could be stored and released by changing the bias.
